channel.title: Contribute to the Jenkins X Project on Jenkins X
channel.description: Recent content in Contribute to the Jenkins X Project on Jenkins X

item.title: Contribute to the code
item.description: Introduction Jenkins X is an open-source project and lives by the work of its contributors. There are plenty of open issues, and we need your help to make Jenkins X even more awesome. You don’t need to be a Go guru to contribute to the project’s development. Assumptions This contribution guide takes a step-by-step approach in hopes of helping newcomers. Therefore, we only assume the following: You are new to Git or open-source projects in general You are a fan of Jenkins X and enthusiastic about contributing to the project If you’re struggling at any point in this contribution guide, reach out to the Jenkins X community in Jenkins X’s Discussion forum.

item.title: Contribute to the Documentation
item.description: Create Your Fork It’s best to make changes to the Jenkins X docs on your local machine to check for consistent visual styling. Make sure you’ve created a fork of jx-docs on GitHub and cloned the repository locally on your machine. For more information, you can see GitHub’s documentation on “forking” or follow along with Jenkins X’s development contribution guide. You can then create a separate branch for your additions.

item.title: Planned Features
item.description: Feature Not Planned Planned In Progress Released Operating Systems macOS 1.1.x Linux 1.1.x Windows In Progress Cloud Providers AWS kops 1.1.x AWS EKS 1.3.x Azure 1.

item.title: Triaging issues
item.description: The main issue tracker for the Jenkins X project is https://github.com/jenkins-x/jx/issues. This aims to capture issues, ideas and development work. If in doubt please raise an issue and a Jenkins X team member will look to triage it as soon as possible. As Jenkins X is using prow from the Kubernetes ecosystem we figured we’d take their lead in traiaging a large number of issues to aid and encourage contributions.
